message: Happy New Year! Wishing you a safe and prosperous 2017.

Tomorrow a new Congress will be sworn in. Here's a look back at some of the most memorable moments from the 114th Congress.  Sign up to receive my newsletter here: https://rodneydavis.house.gov/forms/emailsignup/

Today, I was sworn in to the 115th Congress. I am honored to have another opportunity to represent the people of the 13th Congressional District. Since coming to Congress, my focus has always been on making Washington work for those I represent. We’ve had some successes but I am confident that under this new unified Republican government, we will have many more. I look forward to hitting the ground running by first addressing the government overregulation that has created this part-time economy and hindered the American Dream for too many. This includes repealing and replacing Obamacare, which has left millions of Americans with healthcare costs they cannot afford. The American people sent us to Washington demanding leadership and now they expect action.

President Obama is on Capitol Hill this morning asking members of his party to save his legacy legislation. Here is why we are working to repeal and replace Obamacare:  ✓ 2017 rates for Illinois have increased between 44-55% ✓ Even if you have insurance, 31 million people cannot afford to use it because of high deductibles ✓ Fewer choices because fewer doctors are participating ✓ Fewer plans because more and more companies are dropping from the exchange ✓ Crushing middle class families who do not qualify for govt subsidies but are still forced to pay high costs ✓ It’s not working  Tell me how Obamacare is impacting your family -->

Creating a commission and establishing it as a National Historic Trail will help preserve and celebrate it's history.

The first African American church in Springfield was Official) Zion Missionary Baptist Church of Springfield, Illinois, which was founded  on April 21, 1838. In its beginning, the church served the needs of freed and escaped slaves in the Springfield area, and later became a safe haven for African Americans through the Civil War, Reconstruction, and the Springfield 1908 Race Riots. In 1976 the church relocated to its current location at 16th and Laurel.   Please see the excellent State Journal-Register article from a few years ago on the church's history.

Today in DC, I spoke about student debt, which now represents the second highest form of consumer debt, only behind mortgage debt and my bill to help address it. This is troubling not just for graduates but for our economy and debt. Graduates with large amounts of student debt are less likely to buy a house, purchase a car, or save for retirement. This is a problem for our economy. Another issue are defaults. In 2012, roughly 1.3 million students graduated with student loan debt. 153,400 of those students have since defaulted on their loans leaving 4.5 billion in default liabilities. And that’s just one recent graduating class.  The good news is thought that more and more employers like the ones who spoke today and their clients are recognizing this burden on graduates and have started to offer help. Roughly three percent of private businesses provide some sort of student loan repayment assistance. H.R. 795 will help that number grow by offering tax incentives to businesses who provide the benefit and be tax-exempt for the employee so it’s not counted as part of their income.

Small communities in rural Illinois are at a disadvantage if disaster strikes. I've been working to change that.   The first step to change this will happen in the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee tomorrow when they vote on my bill at 9am CST. You can tune in here: http://transportation.house.gov/calendar/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=401276  Because FEMA uses a state per-capita formula to calculate the need for federal assistance, our communities rarely qualify for assistance when surrounding states do. We've seen this time and time again with the 2015 flooding, Gifford tornadoes in 2013, and tornadoes in Harrisburg in 2012. Each time Illinois was denied. Your pay into the Disaster Relief Fund with your tax dollars so we should have fair consideration.

Illinois $18 million Indiana $9.1 million Missouri $8.4 million Wisconsin $8 million Kentucky $6.1 million Iowa $4.3 million  This is the amount that each of these states need to reach before they qualify for public assistance after a disaster occurs. Illinois is nearly double that of any of our neighboring states. Illinois taxpayers pay into the Disaster Relief Fund so I think it should be there when we need it. My bill to make this more fair for states like Illinois just passed the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee.

Playing politics with funding the government is not the way to go. Every time there is a threat of a government shutdown by either party, it puts our troops and national security at risk, negatively impacts our markets, and jeopardizes our position as a world leader. I’m confident that both parties will come together once again to avert a government shutdown but crisis appropriating is not the way to govern. That's why I've introduced the End Government Shutdowns Act. This bill removes the threat of a shutdown. I want Congress to get back to our regular appropriations process and stop massive, year-end spending deals where the choice is vote for this bill or shut down the government. Instead of relying on these deals negotiated by just a few members of Congress, we should be passing each appropriation bill to give every member a say as we go line-by-line through our budget to reduce and reprioritize spending.

Great news → the House just passed the American Health Care Act to repeal and replace Obamacare.   There has been a lot of misinformation out there so I encourage everyone to read my entire statement before commenting. My statement:   “Americans deserve a health care system that provides a choice of insurance they can actually afford. Many want to pretend Obamacare is working – that it has covered 24 million people or lowered premiums by an average of $2,500 like was promised but neither of those are true. The facts are Obamacare covered less than half of those it promised to cover, premiums in Illinois went up by an average of 45 to 55 percent last year, and 29 million still don’t have insurance coverage even though it’s mandated by the government. People would rather face a penalty than have Obamacare because they’ve seen the 31 million people who pay costly, monthly premiums for plans with sky-high deductibles that drive up out of pocket costs. Seventy-five percent of people in Illinois only have the choice of one or two insurance providers on the exchanges. That is not success.  “President Obama and Democrats in Congress had seven years to fix Obamacare through regulatory reforms, which did not need congressional approval, but failed because the law is fundamentally flawed. Obamacare is collapsing and we have a duty to our constituents to pass a solution. It’s incredibly disappointing that my colleagues on the other side of the aisle – many of whom have acknowledged the law’s failures – refuse to be part of a solution for their constituents who will likely get another notice at the end of the year telling them their premiums have increased yet again or the plan they have no longer exists.  “It’s unfortunate that many of the same groups selling the broken promises of Obamacare seven years ago are now spreading misinformation about the American Health Care Act (AHCA), particularly misinformation about pre-existing conditions. This is insulting to me as someone whose wife is an 18-year survivor of colon cancer – a specific form of colon cancer that is genetic and one I pray my children do not have. This bill does not weaken pre-existing conditions. The same protections currently mandated under Obamacare to prevent insurance companies from discriminating against people with pre-existing conditions, remain. This bill goes a step further than Obamacare to help those with pre-existing conditions by including provisions that not just help people get insurance coverage, but insurance they can actually afford.  “We promised the American people we would do whatever necessary to fix our broken health care system and this bill is just the start. You will continue to see the House pass legislation that focuses on lowering costs and providing better options for all Americans.”

I was honored to be joined by my wife Shannon, who is a nurse and an 18-year cancer survivor, yesterday at the White House to celebrate passage of the AHCA. I promised to protect and help those with pre-existing conditions and that's exactly what this bill does. If you have a pre-existing condition or are concerned for someone who does, please read this: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/ff577e65-a463-404a-b11a-40c8988e8e18/ahca-q-and-a.pdf

Tonight, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee agreed to work to find a solution on tuition waivers as part of tax reform. This is important for graduate students and employees at the universities in my district. Last year, the University of Illinois provided $184 million in tuition waivers to 1,387 faculty and staff last year – 1,100 of those employees made less than $75,000. We want to protect the building services employee or administrative assistant who has worked the same job for 15 years just to send their kid to college can continue to do so without being taxed. I appreciate Chairman Brady's willingness to listen and work with us on this issue. This is how the process should work. Tomorrow, the House will consider the first major tax reform bill since 1986. I am looking forward to voting for a bill that will let middle-income earners keep more of what they earn by simplifying, lowering rates, and doubling the standard deduction to $12k for individuals and $24k for couples filing jointly.

It's people like Fred Vautour, and people like him across the 13th District, that I'm fighting to not only protect qualified tuition waivers that helped Fred put his kids through college, but also pass this bill that simplifies the tax code, helps Americans save more for college through 529 plans, lowers rates for middle-income Americans, and ensures the first $12k/$24k of what Fred earns is tax free. I'm glad Chairman Brady committed to working with us to fix tuition waivers when the bill goes to conference with the Senate and I look forward to voting for the first major tax relief bill since 1986. As a former staffer and someone with a female-led office, I believe this resolution is an important first step in addressing this problem as we work to increase professionalism in the House and establish a workplace that is grounded in respect.   In Congress, we’ve got to lead by example.   As a member of the House Administration Committee, we worked hard to pass reforms last Congress to make House office spending more transparent and accountable than any other area of the federal government and I am confident in this committee’s ability to address this important issue in a bipartisan way.   I look forward to the continued hearings the committee will have on this issue as we work to institute policies that protect staffers against sexual harassment and also ensure female staffers are provided leadership opportunities.   I urge my colleagues to support this important resolution.
